description.text:
This started out as a simple remix to add labels to the "Ring Size Measuring Tool", but quickly got out of hand. I'm not sure if this should be considered a remix since I ended up starting from scratch, but I drew my original inspiration from alexvasilyev's(https://www.thingiverse.com/alexvasilyev) design.

I ended up with a Fibonacci spiral shaped ring size measuring tool with a greater range of sizes than the original, but at the expense of taking out the half sizes.

I also put labels on the sizer to make it easier to see which size each ring is. It's somewhat legible! hah ha. Works good enough for me for now.

title: Nasa space wrench Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is our kit to enhance the Nasa Space Wrench!
The kit is composed by: the Nasa Space Wrench, the unlocker of the wrench and the universal screwdriver joint.
You can find the Nasa Space Wrench here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:608397
https://nasa3d.arc.nasa.gov/detail/wrench-mis

Our universal screwdriver joint is designed to be easly inserted on the wrench pin; once you placed it on the wrench you can use any kind of screwdriver you need.
To secure all the parts, we used two little magnets. The first one is inserted in the pin of the wrench; to do this, we drilled a little hole and then we glued the magnet inside it.
The second magnet was glued inside the squared hole of the universal joint. In this way the screwdriver wouldn’t fall down while using the wrench.

Instructions
We used PLA to print all the kit with a DeltaWASP 20x40 3Dprinter; we used a 0.4 mm nozzle and a 1.75 mm wire.

To print the whole kit we used:

  • 0.15 mm layer height
  • 1.6 mm shell thickness
  • 0.9 mm bottom/top thickness / 0.6 mm for the universal joint
  • 35% fill density
  • 5 brim lines amount
  • 200°C printing temperature
  • 50°C bed temperature

title: Geared Bowden Extruder V2 for flexible

description.text:
Things that are needed for Assembly
5mm axle ~50mm
MK8 drivegear
3 ballbearings 625ZZ
3 M4 screws 30mm with hexbolt.
4 M3 10mm for the motor mount.
1 16T GT2 Pulley
1 60T GT2 Pulley
1 hard spring ( taken from Velleman Vertex K8400 extruder )
1 79T Belt
50mm teflon tube inside it for guiding the filament.
1 or 2 Teflon fittings.
Nema 17 motor

E-steps with 16T and 60T Pulley: 548.27

This is the second version but first to test and still things to improve on, but worked better than i could have imagined.

Did testprint with TPE Torwell Flexible and used retracts, worked really well.
At 60mm/s I got some trouble with extruding plastic, but 40-50 worked well, more testing needed.

Assembly.
Drilled in the Top and Bottom frame piece for the screws and axle. 4 and 5.5mm
Inserted one small teflon tubing from both ways where the filament are supposed to go, and then cutted it after the frame against the MK8 drivegear, inserted PTFE fittings both ways.

Succeded printing in 50mm/s with PTE flexible :)

Printer:

ANet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

25-100

Notes:

I used 25% infill on everything except the arm where i used 100%.
Support are needed on some places where the screws are going.

En el primer video el Camión avanza en línea recta con las rampas traseras bajadas y cara sonriente. Cuando encuentra un obstáculo en el camino sube las rampas y emite un sonido. Al mismo tiempo retrocede mientras gira para cambiar la dirección de la marcha y así poder salvar el obstáculo. En las imágenes se puede ver la programación en facilino.

En el segundo video, el camión recibe órdenes de la app creada con AppInventor 2. Las órdenes que puede seguir son: los movimientos (avanza, retrocede, gira a la derecha, gira a la izquierda), emite sonidos correspondiente a la escala musical, sube y baja las rampas traseras y cambia la cara delantera. La aplicación tiene también un boton para cambiar de modo Control Remoto a modo Automático y un acceso directo a la aplicación de mail para enviar un mensaje al autor del proyecto.

author: Gepetto

description.text:
You should scale it before printing.

Any printer and print setting is fine but be careful about the thin walls while scaling!

I made the following changes:

  • Scaled everything down to 66% so it is slim enough to fit on my flower bench or windowsill
  • Elongated the long sides
  • Added height to the main body
  • Added a baseplate
  • Added support structures (inside and outside rims for the baseplate, inside corner pieces for the main body)
  • Exchanged the support beams for the top roof (I kept the original angle, but I think it is just a bit too obtuse - see 2nd photo)

Please note that this will only turn out usable with a well calibrated and focussed laser. The structures are very delicate.

I cut this from 3mm HDF using an epilog zing at full power and 50% speed. Turned out quite stable. As always, quick-drying wood glue is your friend! As you can see in the 1st photo I used some coated wire to hold the pieces together until the glue was fully hardened.

description.text:
This is Hot End 3 for the Anet A6

I have more than one Anet and the others are only used for ABS and PET-G printing and not very useful for printing PLA. They have no fan for cooling the printed parts and the Heat break is closed in so no air flow will hit the ABS printed part. Also the extruder is still mounted on the X car. ABS printing is not fast, thus I had no reason to make the X car super light.
Lately I print more with PLA because it saves money.
Now I had a Reason to make a Hot End Mod for the Anet to make PLA printing possible again.
My goal was to make the X car as light as possible and to add cooling for the PLA.
So I made a Bowden setup and gave the X car two “snail house fans”. Also I skipped the cable holder and thigh ripped the cables of the X car to the Teflon Tube. And this worked super good :-) .
The Extruder is now mounted above the controller. Also I skipped the housing this printer once had.
Printing PET-G with cooling is another thing. If the object is small ore round it works well. But if the object is big and small warping is just around the corner :-) So for large objects that take the whole print bed I still prefer the old Anet Hot end mod I build for printing ABS.

If you think I forgot something or you have questions, feel free to ask :-)

Parts List:

2x Teflon tube holder clips tube 3 or 4 mm
Teflon tube 3 or 4 mm for 1.75mm filament
Linear bearings that came with the Anet A6 printer (2x LM8UU)
extruder driver gear (also came with the Anet printer)
Nema 17 as Extruder motor (also came with the Anet printer)
Spring for the extruder (also came with the Anet printer)
2x snail house Fan. (one came with the Anet printer)
1X Hot end (heat break cooling fins diameter 22.5mm x 26mm but smaller will fit also)
1X heater block heater and thermistor (came with the Anet printer)
1X Filament pressure wheel for extruder (came with the Anet printer)
1X 30x30mm Fan and holder for Hot End (came with the Hot End)
1X M4 hex key head x 6mm (came with the Anet printer)
2X M4x 45mm and nuts
5X M4x 20mm and 3 nuts
8X M3x 20mm and 5 nuts
4X M3x 10mm and 3 nuts
1X 80mm M3 treated rod and 6 nuts (but I used 2 M3x 40mm bolts instead of the rod in the picture)

In the picture I tried to make clear where the bolts and nuts have to go. On the Extruder the Telfon tubing is not drawn. Also the spring of the extruder is not depicted. Also 2 M3x 20mm bolts that mount into the stepper motor is not shown…. Time is a killer I guess :-)

description.text:
I got tired of having peripherals like hard drives scattered all over my desk, so sat down and designed this in Fusion 360 (be gentle - one of my first designs!). It is designed to hold a couple of 2 1/2" portable hard drives and a larger Le Cie Porsche drive in the bays underneath it. I printed this in PLA and is broken up to fit the bed of a Flashforge Creator Pro. Assemble using appropriate glue for the material you are working in. The lap top holder came from one I designed for the top of the Anet A8, so it has that capability as well. Of course, you will need to print two of those for either version. The drive bays are open on both ends to facilitate ventilation.

TIP: Even when printing using PLA, it has a strong tendency to warp! The ONLY way I found to defeat that, is to print it on a raft with a bed temp of 75 degrees. Use a separation between the raft and part of .15. That let the print come out perfect without any warping and made the raft easy to remove while still keeping the part anchored to the bed. I HIGHLY recommend these settings, but you know your printer. Of course, because of the long throw across the top, supports are needed inside the part. Printed using Simplify 3D, 10% infill, 10% support fill. No support is needed for the Lap top rack itself.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I also added cable organizers found on Thingiverse. Your choice if/what you want to do here. I used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:648212. You can also anchor a USB hub to the side of one of the bays using double stick foam tape if you like (I did).

Carefully remove the raft using your favorite technique. The .15 separation makes it come off easy and clean. The 10% infill support setting gives adequate support to print the tops, while still making them easy and clean to remove using a pair of small needle nose pliers and a twisting motion.

Glue the Lap top supports even with the outside edge of the drive bays. That will give adequate separation to support up to a 15" laptop. I included slight overhangs at the bottom of the rack to ensure the lap top won't pop up out of the rack
Designed in Fusion 360 using components I wanted to organize, but will fit many others. Designed with a 1mm clearance on side and top of the drive bays for the components I designed it for.

Sarcophagus, 250-300 CE, Pantano-Borghese (Italy), marble. Musée du Cinquantenaire (Brussels, Belgium). Made with ReMake and ReCap Pro from AutoDesk.

Bust of the deceased in the center of the tank, volumen (roll of papyrus) in the hands. In front of her, a spherical object is placed on an altar. On each side, a genie (Hypnos or Thanatos?) Supports a drapery (parapetasma). The group is flanked by a peacock and a lion devouring an ibex, in other words animals symbolizing respectively the spiritual survival of humanity and its material destruction by death. This sarcophagus has been reused as a fountain basin.

For more updates, please consider to follow me on Twitter at @GeoffreyMarchal.

description.text:
This is a thermoform cuff bracelet. Small is 16cm, Medium 18cm, Large (pictured) is 20cm.

Pictured in grey PLA+ and wood PLA. Wood PLA works and looks lovely, but it's a bit less sturdy.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:
  • Print using PLA which will bend at a lower temperature, this will not work with ABS.
  • Make sure it's the right way up as there are some very small (.3mm) height differences at the top to give it a little texture.

To shape the cuff:
  • Place it in hot water (approx. 90c/200F) for a few seconds until it softens.
  • Carefully remove it from the water and bend it into shape. You'll need to work quickly as it will cool in a few seconds

Tips:

  • Use tongs to avoid burning yourself. Soft tipped silicone tongs work well.
  • If you're not happy with the shape, just put it back in the hot water and try again.
  • I've found using a small container with rounded edges makes adjusting the final shape easier.

I got the idea for thermoforming a bracelet from Easy Hex Thermoform Bracelet by mathgrrl.

I sketched and extruded this design in Fusion 360.

title: Folded lamp shade spotlight for GU 5.3 bulb

description.text:
This is a remix of the Folded Lamp shade I which found here on Thingiverse and loved it, but wanted to tweak it a little bit for my own needs.

I've split the model in two parts:

  • The actual shade
  • A cover with pre-drilled holes for the standard GU 5.3 connectors. This cover includes holes to allow hot air to escape

Non-printable parts needed:

  • Two M2x10mm bolts to hold the adaptor in place
  • Two 2mm screws to hold the two pieces together
  • 1 GU 5.3 connector
  • 3mm wire

I've used the following print settings with good results:

  • PLA @ 215/210 degrees, 65/60 degrees bed temperature
  • Layer height 2.5mm
  • Infill: 0% up until the screw mounts, 20% honeycomb above that (if your slicer doesn't allow you to select different settings for different regions, I have used 5% rectilinear for the whole print with good results. 20% honeycomb for the top cover
  • 1 Outline/perimeter shells - the part doesn't need any structural rigidity. Plus, using less material helps making the shade translucent.

I have also found it tricky to align the prongs with the connector so I designed a little tool to help push the bulb in/out - also included in the files.

I have used this design successfully with 7W GU5.3 12V bulbs. I suggest you don't try to use regular incandescent bulbs because the heat would most likely cause the part to melt or even worse, catch fire.

UPDATE 21/02/2018

  • Modified the top cover a bit to give some extra room for the wires
  • Changed recommended print settings

author: ycomet

description.text:
This set of things provide examples of graphs of mulitvariable functions. This page is meant to complement the paper "3D Printed Manipulatives in a Multivariable Calculus Classroom" which will appear in PRIMUS.

The three functions used here are:

  • f(x,y) = x^2+y^2
  • f(x,y) = xy
  • f(x,y) = 2xe^(-x^2-y^2)

The "saddle" and "hillpit" models were designed using Mathematica using the Plot3D function with the Filling->Bottom option selected.

The "paraboloid" model was designed using OpenSCAD. The overall design was obtained by using the difference function to cut an inner solid "paraboloid" out of an outer solid "paraboloid" (really, the two solids are offsets of the actual paraboloid). Finally, I flattened out the top for easier printing without supports.

Source files for these models are attached.

The idea is that students will be able to use the models to answer questions about concepts related to functions of two variables like partial derivatives, gradient, critical points, contour plots, and Lagrange multipliers.

After being given the models with some context about the x, y and z coordinates, students can be asked questions about the function, which they can answer and demonstrate using the models. Depending on the intention of the instructor, students may be given an explicit formula for each multivariable function or not.

Questions can include:

  • Sketching a contour plot of the function
  • Finding the partial derivatives or gradient vector at particular points
  • Identifying critical points
  • Sketching a curve along the surface and identifying extrema using Lagrange multipliers

RiGattino è uno strumento per rigare la pasta fatta in casa, in modo gradevole e divertente!

Arrotolate la pasta sopra la faccia con le scanalature per assistere alla rigatura!
Gnocchi, cavatelli e garganelli non saranno più un mistero per voi, con RiGattino in azione!

Uno strumento utilissimo soprattutto per giocare coi bambini e dedicarsi ad attività manuali con spirito ludico.

È cosa risaputa: i gatti veri graffiano;
artigli affilati e sensi felini sempre all'erta!

Ma sapevate che...ogni gatto ha i propri oggetti preferiti?
Conosco un gatto che graffia cordialmente soltanto gli umani non graditi.
Un altro fa esercizi quotidiani sui divani un po' sbiaditi.
C'è poi il gatto ormai educato, che graffia solamente l'oggetto a tira-graffi deputato.
Ebbene, c'è anche un gatto di nome RiGattino,
piccolo, ribelle e birichino.
Graffiava tutto e tutti lungo il suo cammino,
così null'altra cosa da graffiare gli è rimasta,
se non la liscia e bianca pasta!

Che danno, RiGattino, cos'hai fatto?
Penne, gnocchi, ditali e ditalini,
come mai farò con questo gatto matto?

Tutto è ormai rigato per benino,
non c'è pasta senza righe quando passa RiGattino !!!

Sainsmart 5 axis break out board (BOB) for CNC control - I made clips for both the 83.5mm mounting holes and the 54mm mounting holes so that I could mount it in either orientation. I also extended the this clip to 25mm higher than the base clip. The one I have is an older version: https://www.amazon.com/SainSmart-Breakout-Board-Stepper-Driver/dp/B0093Y89J8/

5v power supply - I used this to mount the 5a power supply purchased here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019P1F4E6/
I didn't end up using the clip but the design should be good.

36v power supply - I used this to mount the 9.7a power supply purchased here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HTH0MUE/
I didn't end up using the clip but the design should be good.

Xylotex parallel port breakout board - I made a centered one-hole clip and a 47mm two-holed clip to support this: http://xylotex.netfirms.com/OSCommerce/catalog/product_info.php?cPath=28&products_id=112

TB6600 / HY-DIV268N-5A stepper motor driver - I doubled the width of the clip to make it more stable since, unlike all of the above items, these mounted to the rail with only one clip each.

title: Parametric T-Slot Nut With Option To Make Off-Center

description.text: I needed to make a t-slot nut off-center to adapt a metric pillowblock with 42mm hole spacing to English 1530 80/20 aluminum extrusion with 1.5" t-slot spacing (38.1mm). I also wanted to change the nut holder profile a bit to make it better fit the extrusions I had. The source object was used as a reference but I wrote the .scad file from scratch (for better or worse). The nuts I used were #6 and #10 SAE Nyloc nuts but the dimensions can be changed easily. The nut width specified in the .scad file is for the largest width of the nut.

Got a messy desk and no where to sit your beverage around your Ultimaker or Makerbot?  Cupholder to the rescue!

3) Obtain refreshing beverage.
4) Re-enact commercial quality scene where you loudly open the beverage.
5) Gulp it loudly, and let out a satisfying, "Aaaah!"
6) Place beverage in cup holder.
7) Repeat steps 5 & 6 until beverage is depleted. Changed to more restrictive license due to Makerbot legal changes. Sorry!

title: Parametric Stepper Motor Crank for 1/4" or 6.25mm shaft

description.text: I wanted a stepper motor crank for manually moving the steppers (when unpowered) but my motors have a 1/4" shaft so I designed my own crank. The shaft diameter is parametric (along with the other values) so it should be adaptable to other sizes. The size is perfect for use with a NEMA 23 motor but can be changed. I used an M3-0.5 16mm pan head machine screw and nut to secure the crank on the shaft and an additional M3-0.5 16mm pan head machine screw with washers threaded into the handle. You might need to tap the handle but I was able to directly thread the M3 screw into the handle.

author: mredmon

title: Y belt tensioner for FLSUN cube

description.text:
Newly modified to reduce the height by 5mm.
Not yet printed and tested.
The existing mounts for the Y belts have no adjustment, and are some 12mm lower than where the belts come off the toothed pulleys - the height difference will play havoc with the belt tension. Simple Pythagoras shows a belt length variation of nearly 2mm between carriage at the centre of Y, and carriage at the Y limit..
This modification solves both those issues.
Each belt will need one Ysupport and one Ytensioner - they fit on top of the two X rod mounts, and are fixed using the M3 bolt through the mount clamping hole.
The tensioner should have an extra support on the other side of the rod holder to stop it twisting. If you use it (recommended), the M3x25 will not be long enough. Suggest an M3x30
The tensioners require an extra M3 bolt and couple of nuts (to lock it) tod use the standard H Wheel Holder as in my X tensioner.
The Ysupport has a cut out on one side to enable it to fit against the X motor.

Printer:

Ormerod

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Layer 0.24mm. 40% infill
PETG, 240/65 for first layer 230/60 for the rest.
OpenSCAD

author: Ivailo

title: Parametric Parts for CNC Router and 80/20 Extrusions

description.text:
I've got a lot of miscellaneous parts I designed for my CNC router build (https://openbuilds.com/builds/fixed-gantry-cnc-router-with-old-industrial-supplies.6742/). I used 8mm leadscrews, 16mm linear rails, a 16mm ballscrew, 80/20 series 1530 (1.5" x 3") extrusion, etc but all the files are parametric so they should be easily adaptable to other sizes. I've included here:

router_mount.stl
A mount for holding a 64mm diameter cylindrical object (such as a Harbor Freight trim router) and mounting it to something with 4 SAE #10 1.5" machine screws (such as the z_mounting_plate below).

x_nut_connector_v3.stl
Used with 2 SAE #10 machine screws and t-nuts to attach aluminum extrusion to a standard 8mm leadscrew nut.

x_pillow_block_spacer_v4.stl
A small spacer for something with 42mm mounting holes (such as an 8mm pillowblock).

y_guide_drill_template.stl
y_guide_drill_template_half.stl
y_guide_drill_template_half_trimmed.stl
A drilling template for use with 4 linear rail guides with 4 mounting holes each. It was too large for my print bed so I trimmed it and cut it in half.

y_nut_mount.stl
A mount for a 16mm ballnut (1605).

z_mounting_plate_2_guides_v2.stl
z_mounting_plate_v4.stl
Mounting plate for connecting a router mount (such as found above) to either 1 guide per side or 2 guides per side when the guides are sitting on linear rails mounted to the outside of 80/20 series 1530 aluminum extrusion (see pictures).

z_nut_mount_v2.stl
Used with 2 SAE #10 machine screws to attach a standard 8mm leadscrew nut to the z_mounting_plate above. Should be a drop in part for the OpenBuild anti-backlash nut for 8mm leadscrews (http://openbuildspartstore.com/anti-backlash-nut-block-for-8mm-metric-acme-lead-screw/). Unfortunately, the anti-backlash nut didn't fit my 8mm leadscrew purchased elsewhere.

z_stepper_motor_mount_revised.stl
Adapter to mount a NEMA 23 stepper to the end of an 80/20 series 1530 aluminum extrusion. The adapter is secured to the end of the extrusion after tapping the holes and the stepper is secured to the adapter. See photo.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/g5RARFP7Tpy

Spool for loose filament.

Link to Fusion 360 design (easily changeable parameters to make it in different sizes): http://a360.co/2BDdCvq

I use this to print loose filament (like samples and left overs), the open sides makes it easy to bundle the loose filament with zip ties (if carefully keeping track of the ends it won't tangle) and remove it from the spool.

The spool in the images is printed with PETG and weights 190 grams. I like it sturdy but it can be made with less thickness to save plastic (just change the parameters in Fusion 360). The STL files for download has a spool diameter of 90 mm, inner width of 50 mm and the rim diameter of 200 mm. There are holes for fixing the filament that are 2.1 mm in diameter.

It should be usable for filament refills like this https://www.dasfilament.de/filament-refill/pla-1-75-mm , but I have not tried it. Will update next time I buy filament.

A variety of 2D and 3D OpenSCAD models for windows frames of various styles. 2D models are for etching, laser cutting, scribing, milling etc. 3D models are for additive printing. Can be easily customised for size, aspect ratio and number of glazing bars.

The default files generate a 1:152 model of the following windows:
Arched Window Design 1. This is the arched windows in the winding engine house at Middleton Top on the Cromford and High Peak Railway. Built around 1830 and still there today as can be seen in the photo DSCN1320.jpg
Arched Window Design 2. This is the arched windows in the old engine shed at Middleton Top on the Cromford and High Peak Railway. Now demolished.
Rectangular Iron Windows is also from the Middleton Top winding house, but is typical of many industrial cast iron windows and can be altered to produce any size, or number of panes of glass. The default can be seen in photo DSCN1320.jpg

comments.text: This is a great looking thing! Aesthetically it ties nicely into the overall printer. Two things worry me, and they both come back to HEAT. Its current location has it right under the hot bed, while it probably will not be enough to melt the plastics, I would be concerned about the operation of the RaspberryPi over the long term, so you may want to keep an eye on its operating temp, maybe moving it away from that location if needed. Secondly, if you plan to build an enclosure for your CR-10, it could become an oven in there and cook your Pi. I am planning on using the pi enclosure included with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2774986 as it keeps it away from the heat and enclosure, and gives me a place to store my stuff.

This is a press for making small, disposable containers out of aluminum foil for holding glue or paint. The containers have a shelf that should help with mixing and thinning. If you leave the cup in the press, the reverse side of the press top works as a lid to slow solvent evaporation,

To use:

  • Cut a 5 cm strip off the end of a 30 cm wide sheet of aluminum foil. Divide and cut the strip into four ~7cm lengths.
  • Fold each of these pieces in half and press into a cup shape.
  • Fold the aluminum down over the edge of the press and against the table surface to form a stand.

comments.text: Nice design. Anything to help reduce the clutter on my bench is appreciated.  The base is a little thin and it warped slightly after I removed it from the build plate. (I printed it in PLA and let it cool completely before removing it.)  The tolerances are very tight, so even a tiny bit of warping causes the pieces to rub when spinning. Luckily, Adafruit has the Fusion360 file available to download, so I increased the thickness of the base to 5mm. It's printing now, but I expect it to solve the problem.

description.text:
Yep.  Another printable Iphone stand.  I didn't like many of the others that I had seen though, so I took it upon myself to design one that did all the stuff I wanted it to.  So here's a list of features:  
1)  It's a press fit for the standard 32 pin Iphone connector...no gluing required.  Cord can be coiled inside and routed through the back.  
2)  It's designed to fit an Iphone WITH a phone cover on it.  Crazy idea right?  Almost everyone in the world uses some kind of phone cover.  This won't fit a full on Otterbox, but will work with most other designs  
3)  Built in passive speaker tunnel---not a full on megaphone style, but it will certainly get your attention, and it does actually amplify a fair amount....you can even hear music playback pretty well with it.  
4)  Tabs with through holes to mount directly to a desk or something heavy.  The stand will work on it's own, but I mounted mine to a chunk of steel with some rubber backing on it to keep it in one spot.  
I just moved up to an Iphone 5, so a design for the 5 will be coming soon.
I used an Objet 24 printer to make my piece.

This is a small utility to convert hue-saturation-value colors into RGB colors for use with OpenSCAD's color() module. Check out the instructions tab to see more detail. [Edit: fixed a bug where hue was actually being set by 0-360 not 0.0 - 1.0]

To use it in your own project, download the .scad and put it in your openscad library folder or in the same folder as the project you are using it in. Then, at the top of your script just type: use <hsvtorgb.scad> We've also included this in Customizer! Include it in your customizers by typing: use <utils/hsvtorgb.scad> the useful function in this lib is: function hsvToRGB(h, s, v, a)
give this function a hue, saturation, value, and alpha between 0.0 and 1.0 and it will return a vector with RGBA values in [r, g, b, a] format with values between 0.0 and 1.0

title: Samurai Biker Scout
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I am a Biker Scout in the 501st Legion and wanted to make a Samurai version of the glorious Biker Scout costume from Star Wars.

The entire costume is made of 3D printed parts but also requires a great deal of sewing and time (especially for the lacing). I had a great deal of instruction from the website below.

http://www.sengokudaimyo.com/katchu/katchu.html

I tried to stay as close to original Samurai armor as possible and only made concessions when it needed to be done for the sake of wearability and to adjust the look to match the original Biker Scout costume.

Feel free to ask me any questions. This was a very lengthy build and required a lot of different skills. It's a bit much to list everything here, so just ask away.

Flickr Build Page

https://www.flickr.com/photos/mrpoopie/albums/72157692848687314

title: Vent cover for Zen float tent

description.text:
This is a replacement vent cover for the vents on a zen float tent.

The inner fins on the zen's vent cover have a tendancy to break off, and are a bit annoying to insert into the vent.

This is a "drop in" replacement, with heftier fins that are tapered at the end, for ease of insertion.

Note: The fins are long enough that if you have one on the bottom and top of the vent, the fins can hit each other. So you have to rotate the vents so that the fins from the bottom and top mesh together.

Use this to house a 18x18 GPS and run through your lipo strap on top of your quad.

IMPORTANT: This adaptor will ONLY work if you are using a camera body with an aps-c or "cropped" sensor. This will not work on full frame sensors as the adaptor ring will appear in the field of view, I have tried it on a full frame and you get a black circle covering 20% of your photos.

This is a filter adaptor ring for the Rokinon/Samyang 14mm ultra wide angle lens. This adaptor allows you to use 95mm threaded filters like a circular polarizing filter, Neutral density filter, or other types of filters on this fixed hood lens.

There are no threads on this STL model. A 95mm UV filter is pressed into the top of the adaptor ring. The UV filter acts as the master threads to screw other filters to.

Printing instructions:
-I printed this in black Makergeeks Raptor PLA at 245ºC since it is a high temp PLA that can resist the heat of being left in a car or other hot environments.
-Use black or extremely opaque filament, you don't want any light entering through the sides of the print.
-Use 4 shells to strengthen the thin feature at the top.
-No supports: all angles are at 45º
-Use a thicker layer height like .2mm. This create ridges on the inside of the adaptor that help trap and deflect light, it keeps light from bouncing off the inside of the UV filter and creating glare.

Other things you will need:
95mm UV filter.
I designed this around a ProOPTIC 95mm UV filter to give a nice snug fit, so consider any other brand UV filter untested. Other brands may have a slightly different outer diameter of the filter ring and my not fit with the adaptor I made.

I have the ProOPTIC 95mm filter kit that comes with a UV, circular polarizing, and ND filters. It's a great kit at a good price. You can find it on Amazon and Adoroma

Assembly instructions:
Gently press the 95mm UV filter into the top flange of the adaptor ring with the female threads facing out. Then slide the adaptor ring over the fixed lens hood of the lens. Slide the adaptor down until the lens hood makes contact with the UV filter. The UV filter should rest directly on the lens hood of the lens as shown in the second picture.

It is an overall simple design so it would be very easy for you to make up a new model in Fusion360 to fit your own needs if you want to try and adapt another filter ring diameter.

description.text:
The Geeetech i3 Pro B is a nice entry level printer, but the frame is made from acrylic which is prone to cracking.
One of the more fragile parts is the Y axis motor holder, which will crack if tightened just a bit too much.
It's also a bit short, meaning that when it's fully seated the motor sits at an angle.
Another problem with the original mount is that it will not make the belt level with the mounting point on the bed.

This part is an easy print that solves all of the above problems.

description.text:
Since the PanelDue 7i is still relatively new (as of 2/19/18), there wasn't any cases/mounts available... until now! This case and mount combination is designed to attach securely to 3030-series (EDIT: And now 2020 as well!) extrusions while also providing a way of positioning the screen exactly where you want it. The PanelDue itself is held snugly inside of the case, but access to the screen and the connectors on the back of the panel is unrestricted.

What you'll need in addition to the printed parts:

M3X30mm screws, qty 4 (used to screw the front and the back half of the case together)
M3X6mm screws, qty 4 (used to screw the mount onto the back of the case. Could be longer [M3X10 should be fine] without running into the back of the PanelDue 7i PCB)
M3 nuts, qty 8.

M5x10mm, qty 2 (used for mounting the bracket to the 3030 extrusion)
M5 T-nuts, qty 2.

title: 35mm Din Rail Clip with dummy screw

description.text:
Simple Din Rail Clip with dummy screw head

Inspired and based on thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:725188
The DXF file available there is extremely useful.

There are two .STL versions:

Simple Screw/Without crossbar - This version just emulates a screw head.
Crossbar - this version just adds a little bar on the screw for additional strength/grip. Most Keyslot-type holes do not support this, so you will need the simple screw version.

This was made to mount some Mikrotik routers and switches to DIN Rails.
As all equipment slightly differs, I doubt the .STL files will suit your needs.
I included the .f3z archive so you can adapt it to your needs. It should include the DXF file from mikiCZ too.
A lot of dimensions can already be changed by simple modifications to the (user) parameters:

  • clamp_width: width of the clamp

  • screw_depth: overall height of the screw object
  • screw_shaft_dia: diameter of the screw shaft
  • screw_head_depth: thickness of the screw head

  • screw_head_dia diameter of the screw head

title: Cajetín para reciclar rollo filamento SmartMaterials de 1 kg, como organizador 2.0. (Box for recycling filament roll SmartMaterials of 1 kg, as organizer 2.0?)

description.text:
Cuando decidí reciclar los rollos de filamento vacios, vi un cajetin aquí en thinviverse, el cual tengo en "hechos" (https://www.thingiverse.com/make:448163) pero que no me venia bien, era un poco más grande.
Entonces, decidí diseñar otro con las medidas que necesitaba, este lo tengo en "mis diseños" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2794324). Este es un poco más pequeño, con las paredes más finas y la pestaña para abrir más pequeña, para gastar menos plastico.
Con esta, al imprimirla, surgió un problema, que la base de la pestaña, al ser más pequeña, por warping, no tengo cama caliente, se levantaba y al pasar la tobera del ventilador de capa, chocaba y el extrusor se descalibraba y se iba por otros lugares de la cama teniendo que parar la impresión. Así que decidí hacer la versión 2.0.
En esta versión tenemos:

-Quitar la pestaña. (cajeta_smart2_0)
-Hacerle un agujerito para poner un tornillo para enroscar un pomo. Con Freecad al atravesar la pared curva con un cilindro, resta de piezas, me daba error, al hacerlo con un cubo no había problema, por eso el agujero es cuadrado.
-Hacer un pomo (POMO) para abrir el cajetín: al pomo no le he hecho el agujero para el tornillo, pero con un pequeño taladro y una broca, lo hacemos al tamaño del tornillo.
-Hacer dos modelos más, uno con una separación (cajeta_smart2) y otro con dos (cajeta_smart3).
-Para el agujero del rollo había pensado en utilizarla para meter cosas, pero al poner tres alturas, era dificil coger algo pequeño que metieras, así que decidí poner un portalapices, el fondo es redondo para no tener que ponerle soporte a la hora de imprimir, se puede sacar facilmente por si queremos meter alguna goma de borrar, clips, etc. (PORTALAPICES).
-Al unir los rollos con las barras roscadas con tuercas, me di cuenta de dos cosas: que en lugar de poner tres, ponia dos y la separación central la podía hacer con tuercas, que además servirían para que girara el cajetín (podeis poner una arandela pequeña si lo creeis necesario, yo no lo hice pero creo que lo haré), y segundo, las tuercas inferiores podrían rayar la mesa o la superficie donde pusieramos el conjunto. Por esto ultimo decidí hacer la base (BASE). Esta tiene el radio optimo para que pueda imprimirse con mi Anycubic Kossel Pulley. Los agujeros de la base es para gastar menos filamento, el vastago interior se podría poner hasta que chocara con el portalapices pero no lo vi necesario. Algunos han diseñado un vastago interior con rodamientos para que ruede mejor. Este no girará demasiado pero creo que no es necesario dependiendo de donde coloqueis el aparato. Los agujeros se pueden aprovechar para meter cositas aunque para cojerlas tendreis que sacar los rollos.
Espero que os guste, además reciclaremos los rollos de filamento.
Nota: en la base le pegué Goma-Eva.
Traducción Google:
When I decided to recycle the empty filament rolls, I saw a box here in thinviverse, which I have in "facts" (https://www.thingiverse.com/make:448163) but that did not suit me, it was a little bigger .
Then, I decided to design another one with the measurements I needed, this one I have in "my designs" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2794324). This is a bit smaller, with the thinner walls and the smaller opening tab, to spend less plastic.
With this, when printing it, a problem arose, that the base of the flange, being smaller, by warping, I do not have a warm bed, it got up and when passing the nozzle of the layer fan, it collided and the extruder was decalibrated and I went to other places in the bed, having to stop printing. So I decided to do version 2.0.
In this version we have:

-Remove the tab. (cajeta_smart2_0)
-Make a hole to put a screw to screw a knob. With Freecad when crossing the curved wall with a cylinder, subtraction of pieces, I gave error, when doing it with a cube there was no problem, that's why the hole is square.
-Make a knob (POMO) to open the box: the knob I have not made the hole for the screw, but with a small drill and a drill, we do the size of the screw.
-Make two more models, one with a separation (cajeta_smart2) and another with two (cajeta_smart3).
-To the hole in the roll I had thought to use it to put things, but when putting three heights, it was difficult to take something small that you put, so I decided to put a portaplays, the bottom is round to not have to support it when printing , can be easily removed if we want to put some eraser, clips, etc. (PORTALAPICES).
-When joining the rolls with the threaded rods with nuts, I realized two things: that instead of putting three, I put two and the central separation could be made with nuts, which would also serve to turn the box (you can put a small washer if you think it necessary, I did not do it but I think I will), and second, the lower nuts could scratch the table or the surface where we put the set. Therefore, I decided to make the base (BASE). This has the optimal radius so that it can be printed with my Anycubic Kossel Pulley. The holes in the base is to spend less filament, the inner rod could be placed until it collided with the clip holder but I did not see it necessary. Some have designed an inner rod with bearings to make it roll better. This will not rotate too much but I think it is not necessary depending on where you place the device. The holes can be used to put little things but to take them you will have to remove the rolls.
I hope you like it, we will also recycle the filament rolls.
Note: I hit Goma-Eva on the base.

description.text:
After upgrading to a Bondtech BMG + E3D V6 hot end, I struggled to find a part cooler that fit my needs. j3stef's original design came really close, so I decided to remix it to meet my needs better. Hopefully others will find it helpful too!

If you wish to print the lower grid and caps separately I also provided 05 - A - Lower Grid.stl and 05 - B - My Caps.stl separately.

author: UL42

description.text:
System for quickly changing out the print head on a 3D printer.
Designed originally for my Anet A8, can be easily modified and adapted to fit other models of 3D printers.
My Anet A8 is no longer what it once was, as I have converted it to a CoreXY design based loosely on Tech2C's Hypercube.
If you are just printing this for the Anet A8, you only need the carriage plate, locking levers, and the Anet print head assembly mounting plate.

The carriage plate is designed to bolt directly to the bearing blocks on the Anet A8.
The locking levers flip up to release the tool head, down to lock it into place.

The nuts and screws I used are American #6 machine screws and nuts.

The bearing bracket, belt clamp and belt tensioners are for the CoreXY design.

A set of Arkham Horror CG tokens that can be printed without a need for supports.
Printable on a Prusa i3 MK3 at 0.15mm, and includes horror, damage, clue, doom and resource tokens.

Both STL and Blender files are included, to make it easy for anyone to print or modify.

If you make modifications for other printers and resolutions, I'm happy to include links here!

Model-specific notes

Horror token

Makes use of the sculpting feature in Blender:
https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/dev/sculpt_paint/sculpting/introduction.html#overview

Damage token

I looked around to see if I could find a heart model to modify, but decided in the end that it would probably be more expedient to create the mesh myself, from the ground up, looking at sketches and images. It had to be a single, closed mesh, and I wanted it to be printable without adding supports in the slicer, so this was the most difficult of them.
But I worked it out somehow! :D
The Blender file for this exists in 3 versions:

  • A high detail one, which was the original. After testing a print, I decided to add material between a few arteries to make it less fragile.
  • That became the medium detail model, which is used for the larger 3 health tokens.
  • For the smaller 1 health tokens, I then cut away a few of the smaller arteries and enlarged one or two of the others, to make a low detail model.

Doom token

I had an issue with the first two-colour print of the doom token being too fragile in the connection between tendrils and base. This seems to have been solved by increasing the surface area of the connection slightly, upping the nozzle temperature slightly, and waiting until the print has cooled down. Obviously, I can still break off the tendrils if I want to, but it takes considerably more force.
For doing multi-colour prints, you can use ColorPrint to insert an M600 command between layers in your .gcode, which will instruct the printer that you want a filament change (if your printer supports it):
https://www.prusaprinters.org/color-print/

Resource token

This is actually the first model I made. It shows some slight artifacts in the corners and overhangs on my prints, but probably nothing you will care about. Using a smaller nozzle diameter may help, but I haven't got that yet.

Clue token

Nothing special to note on this one. I'm wondering if I can come up with a more inspired design for it. I'll update it (or simply add the new design) if that happens.

Note of warning

These tokens are small, swallowable things, so obviously you should keep them away from children and animals that might be liable to try and eat them.
Especially the doom tokens. They are pointy, and also, they might use their unwitting host as a blood sacrifice to bring unspeakable horrors into our dimension.

title: Locking Plate for Flat Pack Camera Arm

description.text:
This part is a mod for my flat-pack camera arm design - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2266891

This Thingiverse page provides the part files for the camera arm locking plate. I've written a tutorial on the process of how to cast low-temp metal alloys using 3d printed molds up on Adafruit- https://learn.adafruit.com/metal-parts-from-3d-prints/

The process involves common tools and supplies - a 3d printer, silicone rubber, a hot plate, stovetop casting alloy, and a dollar store skillet. This method can be used to cast a variety of materials, from chocolate to plastic, with the accuracy only limited to the precision and resolution of your printer.

I built a camera arm to document projects a few months ago. The joints are clamped down with rubber pads between them to prevent slipping, but I noticed the joint at the base kept creeping down over long periods of time (like while capturing time lapses). I decided to fix it with a locking plate like you'd find on C-stands, but wanted to avoid using a printed part that would chew itself apart after a few months of use.

I built the locking plate using a method similar to the one I used to generate the waxes that are part of the Glaucus manufacturing process - https://learn.adafruit.com/soft-quadruped-robot-glaucus/introduction

More details on the project - https://har.ms/blog/metal-parts-3d-prints
Tutorial on building the locking plates - https://learn.adafruit.com/metal-parts-from-3d-prints/
Video of the locking plate fabrication process - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qqqVS_YyWzo
Source files for the camera arm - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2266891

comments.text: What's the order that you design these in?  Design the part, design the mold, design the mold-for-the-mold?  Does solidworks allow you to "invert" a model to make it exactly fit against the surface of another one?
comments.author: gangstead

comments.text: Yup! That's the order, though it's helpful to go back and forth between the different models (part, mold, bathtub mold) to check that everything's thought through. SW makes this easy - you can have all the different models as different configurations of the same part rather than separate files. This means that you can change a variable (like the diameter of the locking plate) and have the change cascade down through the mold and the bathtub.

title: Variable Spacing Customizable Hex Bit Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This file allows the user to make custom hex bit holders for parts with variable tool radii. While the hex bit size stays the same, some tools such as hex sockets have variable widths depending on the size of the socket. This design incorporates a recursive function which calculates a new spacing for each individual part, such that there is enough room on the holder to include all of the parts. This design currently only works in 1 dimension for the purpose of spacing the parts. It cannot, at this time, create multiple rows of parts like the original.

Remixes and "I made one" reports are strongly encouraged to help me and everyone else improve our work. If you have any odd experiences with the code, let me know and I might be able to help. I have tried to test this with lots of odd inputs to find issues, but I can't have found everything.

Extra special thanks goes out to the original designer xchg_dot_ca for changing the license on his original work to allow me to publish this remix.

description.text: This cone is part of a lesson for a multivariable calculus class in which students learn how to make sense of a function whose domain is a surface in three dimensions. The cone is meant to model the surface defined in cylindrical coordinates by the equation z=r. This page is meant to complement the paper "3D Printed Manipulatives in a Multivariable Calculus Classroom" which will appear in PRIMUS.
I used OpenSCAD to design the cone, using the difference function to subtract a smaller solid cone from a larger one. The source code is included.

In multivariable calculus, topics like Lagrange multipliers and surface integrals of scalar-valued functions rely on being able to think about a function of three variables restricted to a surface. The idea for this lesson is to get students thinking about how to visualize such a function.

Students should be given the model of a cone along with the defining equation z=r with z<3. They are then told that the function f(x,y,z) gives the distance from (x,y,z) to the point (3,0,0). Students then must sketch contours of the restriction of f to the surface on the model. One can also ask questions about the average value of f along the surface, and the minimum value of f on the surface.

In the photograph, I had a student draw with a marker, but the model can also be blackboard painted for re-usability.

description.text:
Solution: A mount plate to shift your 100mm VESA-mount monitors by 40mm.

Problem: I bought 3 monitor/arm stand and the arms weren't quite long for my monitors. This mount plate offsets the side monitors by 40mm's fixing the bevel edges of the monitors from overlapping.

Designed in OpenJSCAD (what, I like JS) I included the source so you can tweak it. The 100mm VESA spacing and 40mm offset are variables you can tweak along with a few others.

Two prints of this has supported my two 27" monitors for a few weeks. If yours comes crashing down, don't blame me. My first test print was a with less layers/infill than my second but both are holding fine.

I recommend mounting with washers even though the ribbing kind of gets in the way. My second monitor has a stronger print and I didn't use washers there. No signs of degradation on either print so far, after about 3 weeks.

title: Anet A8 X Carriage and E3D v6 mount

description.text:
I got the idea for this from various other designers on Thingiverse.

The belt keeper on the back of the X Carriage was derived from Don1337's "Anet A8 E3D V6 Bowden MODULAR X Carriage V4 BEST ONE" found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193695

The Extruder mount and cooling fan duct design was derived from SCOTT_3D's "Hypercube Evolution" found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2254103

NOTE: I will make small adjustments to the designs to suit troubles you guys might be experiencing, but I am sorry I just don't have the time to add other mounts for things like height sensors, different fan ducts and the like.

Any feed back is welcome,

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40-60

Notes:

I changed the original designs up a little to suit my tastes and I am sharing with you since it has worked out to be a very good set up. Many thanks to the original designers for their ingenuity.

If your printer is on point, and it'll negotiate small openings like bolt holes and the like without support then do not add supports, with exception to the mount opening for the fan duct.
If you do use supports and your slicer allows it, then add the thinnest you can as it is quite cumbersome to fish out the supports out of the screw and nut holes on the Extruder Mount.

X Carriage

This X Carriage is designed to mount to the A8's existing bearing blocks using M4mm screws.
Take note the the top left and right screw holes need to be left open until installing the extruder mount as those two holes are M4mm as well.

There are 2 holes in the bottom left and right hand corners that hold (2) M4mm nuts.

Extruder Mount

There are 4 holes in each corner of the mount that secure it to the X Carriage.
These screws are M4mm.
The top (2) screw will secure into the top bearing blocks of the X Carriage and the bottom screws are secured to (2) M4mm nuts that will need to be added to the X Carriage.

You'll notice 2 slits in the top of the shelf that the hotend mounts to, on each side of the hotend. This is where you will need to slide in (2) M3 nuts that the retainer screws into.
If you add supports for this it will be a pain to dig out. I think the they are narrow enough that no support is needed..

Supports are needed in the square cavity that the cooling ducts slides into.
This is the only area on whole assembly that I applied supports and it came out great.

The cooling fan uses one M3mm hex head or cap head screw.

Retainer

The hotend Retainer uses 2 M3mm hex head screws, that screw into the installed nuts on the Extruder Mount.

You will notice a raised area on one side of the retainer.
This is a visual reference that that side should be facing up.
There is a slight difference in the screw alignment if it is upside down.
It will still work, but the misalignment is noticeable.

Cooling Fan Duct

The fan duct uses 2 M3mm hex head screws and the mounting holes are slightly slotted for minor height adjustments to your hotend nozzle.

title: A Holder of temperature sensitive elements

description.text: A Holder of temperature sensitive elements can best be used in an experiment of a flow in liquids, where it would be very difficult for a teacher to perform the experiment by himself. A teacher has to be able to hold the holder with a test tube and simultaneously set two temperature sensitive elements in the right height to be able to see a temperature difference, which is of interest to us. The teacher would usually have to pick out one of the students to help him with the experiment. This way the teacher will be able to run the experiment alone.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,15mm

Infill:

15%
CCSS
A Holder of temperature sensitive elements

A Holder of temperature sensitive elements
  1. Get the device ready. (A computer with a required SW to measure temperature, a test tube fixed in the holder, temperature sensitive elements fixed in the holder of temperature elements and sensitive elements properly placed in a test tube.
  2. The experiment is divided into two parts.
  3. First part. Pour water of a room temperature into a test tube and start heating it up on the lower side over a burner. We watch a rise in the temperature of the lower side of the test tube as well as the upper side where the temperature sensitive elements are placed.
  4. The first part of the experiment is finished when the temperatures have been compared.
  5. Second part. Take another identical test tube and pour water of the room temperature into the test tube, difference being that we now heat up the test tube its centre area. The sensitive elements are placed the same way as in the first part of the experiment. Watch as the temperature in the upper part of the test tube rises more significantly than in the lower part.
  6. The experiment is finished when the temperatures have been compared.
ABS

title: Adapter for Makita 10.8V batteries in a Proxxon tool

description.text: This adapter allowed me to power a Proxxon 10.8V cordless angle grinder using the battery of a Makita cordless drill. Both types of batteries have the same same cross-section, so the adapter had to be made in two parts: a plug+socket for the electrical connections, and a separate collar for holding it in mechanically.

The electrical contacts were cut out of 0.3mm thick bronze sheet, folded and fitted inside the grooves of the 3D-printed connector body, but slightly thicker metal would have been better.

The socket and plug halves of the connector body were screwed together using three 2.5x16mm woodscrews that were cut shorter.to fit the thickness of the part.
I used QCad Community Edition to draw the 2D profiles in DXF-format, and OpenSCAD to extruded and combine them into 3-dimensional parts.

This hack worked for me, but I do not take any responsibility that it would work for you. It may be unsafe to use an electrical device in a way not intended by its manufacturer. I am showing it here only to share information, not to encourage anyone to actually replicate it.

print_settings.Notes:: A simple design that does not need much tweaking at all.

description.text:
ABS is a great plastic, but its hygroscopic properties cause it to absorb humidity from the air. This has two nasty effects. First it swells the plastic slightly and this distorts the fine tolerances many 3-D printers expect, and can cause blockages, jamming and stretching of Bowden tubes etc The second is the high temperature required to print in ABS is around 240C and the moisture content can turn to steam as the plastic is extruded, causing spitting and erratic plastic flow. Now that I am on my second print head (the first died from causes most likely from the above problems), I was determined to work out how to store my plastic filament better.

My wife provided the inspiration. We have two problems in our downstairs rooms. In winter they have condensation on the windows and mould develops in cupboards. In summer we can have sea mists come in off 90 Mile Beach and the relative humidity shoots up to 70+%. So I remembered she buys plastic buckets that dehumidify the rooms.

I asked for one, then rigged up an old computer cooling fan and a plastic storage box. In went the reels. I left them for a matter of weeks and when I returned to the 3-D printing the creamy, bubble free ABS was delightful. So to show my gratitude and boost sales (not serious of course) of Dehumidifier kits I designed a proper fan mount and a rotating exhaust vent to direct the dry air towards the reels. It also allows me to keep a supply of dehydrated bags of silica to put into plastic bags for long term storage or filament.

Just note though, as the dehumidifier chemical works, it dissolves itself, this resulting liquid is strongly caustic (ie can burn skin) so see below, and follow the manufacturers directions of how to dispose safely.

Notes:

A simple design that does not need much tweaking at all.

Refinements

I simply made the vent a slip in fit. It does not lock in, but the fan I used does not generate enough pressure to require that degree of fitting. It could be glued of course, or the OpenSCAD edited to make a more 'snap' fit. The vent is provided to direct the air stream away form the fan intake and force it circulate more around the box. It could easily work in a bigger storage box. The Dehumidifier lasts quite a while, so it could do many rolls of filament at the same time.
(PS it also was invaluable in drying out my mobile phone after a very quick dip in the salty lake water!!! Though only after very quick rinse in fresh water and then alcohol.)
I have added the OpenSCAD files for people to adapt the system to other dehumidifiers (a complete system could be printed as the dehumidifier chemical can be bought in bags and systems recharged).

Measurement and WARNING

I had a spare weather station Temperature and Humidity detector, and while it is not very accurate, it indicates the humidity is constantly around 30%RH. I am much happier with that than 70%RH!!!

WARNING: Just be careful as the active chemical is strongly alkaline and can burn, and be corrosive at the concentrations it accumulates in the bottom of the canister. When you dispose of it, flush it away with plenty of fresh water eg empty it into a toilet. Do not leave it where children can access it. In a well sealed plastic storage box it should work for many months.

title: CR-10 S5 Y Axis Belt Tensioner

description.text:
This Is a Y Axis Belt Tensioner designed for the CR-10S 500 x 500 x 500. I had issues with the fitment and function of other Y Belt Tensions. One resulted in a structural fail of the print during printing. This design is similar to other tensioner But I designed it using the stock aluminum bracket. It is a total of 5 parts. I did however use the STL for the knob from another Tensioner. There was no need to design a new one. The frame was seperated into a left and right bracket. The puller was modified to have a thicker base. On another puller I had the hex bolt pulled through the hole. I believe my design is much easier to assemble and is sturdier.

still requires a M5 x 16 mm button cap screws and M5 nylon lock nut. a M5 by 30mm hex cap bolt and M5 nut.

Update: I made the bottom of the Puller thicker for the M5 Hex cap bolt. under extreme tension the bolt may be pulled through.

Most pieces can be printed with a 20% infill. I recommend the Puller and the End Cap at least 50%

title: Powerful Continuous Rotation WiFi Servo Winch

description.text:
This is a servo winch with a few Watts of power. This winch can easily raise and lower 1 kg.

This device uses optical sensors to measure the rotation of the shaft and uses a motor and microcontroller to control the position of the winch to within 1/24th rotation (about 5mm in this instance.) A WiFi-enabled microcontroller (WeMos D1 mini) is used so that the position of the winch can be controlled from a browser e.g. smartphone. You can also command the servo through a USB serial connection.

A standard H bridge motor driver is used to power the motor. In the pictures I'm using 1/2 of a dual H bridge which happens to contain a 5V regulator suitable for powering the D1.

A small printed circuit board carries 2 infrared photo-interrupters to make an optical rotary quadrature encoder. Gerber files for the PCB are provided.

NOTE that PLA is not opaque to infrared. I had to paint my rotary encoder blades black to get the photo-interrupter to work reliably.

The model can be changed to accommodate other motors, shafts, gear ratios, etc. You model the parts and the part alignment and the housing is generated automatically.

ALL source code is on github. If you're interested in following this project use github: https://github.com/jesseparker/servowinch

https://youtu.be/ne80NvGg7cM

author: produino

description.text:
I needed to provide a crystal ball for a fortune teller to use in an upcoming theater production. I found a great LED kaleidoscope globe for a few dollars at the craft store. It was great except for the base. I thought it looked too modern. I made this to cover the existing base.

In order to make this, I took measurements of the existing base, which is basically a cone intersected with a shallow cylinder. I found a vector molding profile I liked from a home improvement website and did a rotate extrude of it in OpenScad. I picked 12 faces to match up with the twelve zodiac symbols.

Zodiac symbols are from here: https://www.dafont.com/zodiac-s.font

description.text:
For some time now, I've wanted a way to run my Baofeng on batteries that could be recharged in the field, off of a solar panel or other USB device. Since I use an 18650 battery charger as a power bank and run my headlamp on an 18650, this seemed like the best cell to use.

Two small squares of brass with nubs of solder on them form the primary contacts between the cells and the radio. The brass I used was cut from a strip 13mm wide by 0.5mm thick.

Two ends of a small spring I purchased from the local hardware store (~6.5mm⌀) keep the batteries held fast. They're connected by a diode to prevent reverse polarity from frying your radio.

This is a major work in progress. Though it's functional, it's not very refined. The springs are a bit tricky to solder since they need to be soldered in place with the current design--not optimal. The brass plates also don't make contact with the radio without blobs of solder. I'll most likely update it at some point.

description.text:
UpdateV2: 2/21/18

The Fan shroud Mount has been Improved as the first version's shroud was slightly tilted to the left of the extruder nozzle. Version two has been updated with an improved design so that the shroud itself is centered and should align with the extruder nozzle!

Happy Printing & Enjoy!

v1: 2/18/18
Today I discovered a model for a different Printrbot here on Thingiverse, created by TechnoSwiss, that would actually work quite perfectly with my friend's Printrbot Jr 1307 as both printers share the very same extruder assembly design for the fan to mount onto the extruder. You can view TechnoSwiss original submission by viewing the "Remixed With" section on this page.

To install this model, all you need to do for your Printrbot JR 1307, is to unscrew your fan from the cnc cut part it currently is attached to. Then, remove this part that the fan was attached to on the printer, exposing the 4 pegs that the square cnc part was connected to. Using these pegs, take this model and attach to them instead! The model contains provided screw holes to reattach your fan to.

Voila! You will now have a fantastic fan shroud for your Printrbot JR 1307.

Special Thanks goes out to the original designer: TechnoSwiss

Photo credit for Print: Robert Teal

Happy Printing & Enjoy :-) !!

title: Pandoras Box Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pandora's Box Designed by Benjamin D. Stanley, Artist Kamil Jadczak

Pandora's Box provides a simple and deep abstract party game for a group of players to analyze how well they know the strategic planning of their friends. Each player receives a few white and black stones (good and evil spirits) that they drop into a box in the center of the play area. They may also switch the stones in their hands with other players throughout the game. When someone drops her last stone into Pandora's Box, the box is opened, its contents revealed and taken by the player who opened it, and each player scores points for white stones in hand and loses a point for black stones in hand.

Though it sounds incredibly simple, the game is fast, deep, thrilling, and offers tremendous psychological fun and unexpected results. Despite having no random elements, it has plenty of hidden information that makes each game play out differently.

author: bmfinn

description.text:
So, I wanted to reduce the fan noise, however only found a few options. So I decided to rebuild the nozzle.

Enhancements:
• Lowered profile hot-end Nozzle cooling improving bridging..
• Widened the interior wire channel to make it easier to install and remove.
• Larger air cavity to allow more even airflow while moving the fan externaly.
• Lowered the fan speed requirements by redirecting the rear duct back through the hotend.
• Thicker print walls
• Added internal air channels for better control where the cooling went.

*Notes:
Included a printable fan plate for drilling holes for the external fan mounts.
Simply mirror the mesh to get both left and right-side extruder profiles.
Also included the original Solidworks part for any additional changes you may want to make.

Optional:
Now I wanted to use a Noctua fan to completely remove the fan noise. So I changed to a 40x40x20 12v fan.
You can either mount with screws or just hotglue it to the housing.
I ran my cables within the air chamber and through-hole I drilled for a cable way hiding all the fan power cords.
I simply connected two 12v leds in series with the fan acting as a voltage divider to power my fan on 24v.
What you do with the lights are completely up to you? I connected one to the lower end and upper lighting up the logo for fun. Hope you enjoy.

The Enhanced LED version is also available. It uses a 12v Festoon LED. You can get them here. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01F3AQM0S/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

print_settings.Notes:: For the tow hook, use ABS. Use 4 layers top and bottom, 2 perimeters, and 70% infill. I used .48mm extrusion width and 150% width on infill. Brim will help keep the corners down but it's not important since this part will be embedded into the plane. You will need supports for the notch in the base and for the tip of the hook.

title: Caipirinha 2 Winglets and Towhook for Bungee launch

description.text:
This is the winglet, and a hook for bungee launching, for the TBS Caipirinha 2.

The winglets are an exact replica of the coroplast winglets in the kit, but with sealed edges and more strength. They only weigh 5 grams more than the coroplast if you follow my settings below.

The tow hook is designed for a 1" diameter key ring.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

12 and 70%

Notes:

For the winglets in ABS, use 2 layers on the bottom, 3 layers on the top, 3 perimeters, and 12% infill. I used .48mm extrusion width (with a .40mm nozzle) and 150% width on infill. Use rectilinear infill in one direction one layer, 90 degrees to that in the next layer. If you follow this exactly your winglets will not warp after removing them from the bed. Be sure to use 15 to 20 lines of brim also to help keep it on the bed during printing. I printed one mirrored so I could present the smooth face of the print outboard on each side of the plane.

For the tow hook, use ABS. Use 4 layers top and bottom, 2 perimeters, and 70% infill. I used .48mm extrusion width and 150% width on infill. Brim will help keep the corners down but it's not important since this part will be embedded into the plane. You will need supports for the notch in the base and for the tip of the hook.

For installing the tow hook, locate the pull point of the tow hook at 2/3rd's the distance to the CG from the front edge of wood battery box (4.5"), on the aircraft centerline. Cut a matching square through the foam right up to the wood battery box. Be careful not to cut into the wood. This will expose a former near the leading edge.You will also partly expose one of the battery straps (about half the width of the strap). Rough up the base of the Tow hook print with course sandpaper and wipe off the dust. Be sure the battery strap that was exposed is in a good orientation to install or remove your battery. Then load up the area with GOOP glue, where ever the tow hook will contact the Caipi2. Press in the tow hook and let dry 48 hours prior to bungee launching. Again be sure the battery strap that gets glued into place is in a good position that you can thread and unthread it around the battery, Once the glue sets you will no longer be able to move that strap. I cut away half of my strap width when I glued my tow hook in, so the tow hook could be flush to the wood, but you don't have to do this.

comments.text:

comments.author: TheCure

comments.text: Use rectilinear infill instead. Use it one direction for one layer, then 90 degrees to that in the next layer, and alternate like that for the entire infill. I recommend a .40mm nozzle and .48mm extrusion width, 150% extrusion width for infill

title: Filament Bushing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For my 3d Printer table I used something called Creform, commonly used for tables and shelves in manufacturing environments. Creform is a very useful tool, its basically like an adult erector set. I have a bunch of this stuff and use it for everything. If you want to get some of see how it works check out their website. http://www.creform.com/ If you want to buy their stuff you need to sign up for an account on http://diy.creform.com/Default.aspx.

The standard diameter of the tubing is 28mm, so I made this bushing to help my filament roll better on the creform. It is threaded inside and on the end end so the filament does not come off of the bushing. It fits most standard 1kg rolls of filament.

Print one of each for each roll on the creform spool holder. In my case just a tube running along the side of the machine.

I also included the .f3d file so you can modify.

Update, added some pictures. No longer work in progress, no changes to files. Works great. Remember the inside diameter was made to fit a 28mm pipe. You can edit in the f3d file but dont let the walls get to thin around the threads.

Creality CR-10S
